title: 105_hr3679
content: AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR UNITED STATES CUSTOMS SERVICE AND IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE. To enhance border investigative resources on the Southwest border, combat drug smuggling and money-laundering, and reduce traffic waiting times, appropriations are authorized for the United States Customs Service and INS. This includes $161,248,584 for fiscal year 1999, $185,751,328 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for subsequent fiscal years. To enhance enforcement and inspection resources on the Southwest land border, appropriations are authorized for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. This includes $113,604,000 for fiscal year 1999, $121,064,000 for fiscal year 2000, and necessary sums for subsequent fiscal years. For fiscal year 1999, $48,404,000 is allocated for the United States Customs Service to enhance narcotics enforcement and cargo processing technology along the Southwest border. This includes funding for Vehicle and Container Inspection Systems, mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, and pallet x-rays. The allocation for fiscal year 1999 includes funding for various equipment upgrades and additions for the United States Customs Service along the Southwest border. This includes mobile truck x-rays, fixed-site truck x-ray upgrades, pallet x-rays, portable contraband detectors, contraband detection kits, ultrasonic container inspection units, automated targeting systems, and rapid tire deflator systems. The allocation for fiscal year 1999 includes funding for equipment upgrades and additions for the United States Customs Service. This includes automated targeting systems, rapid tire deflator systems, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, weigh-in-motion sensors, and AM radio stations. The allocation for fiscal year 1999 includes funding for equipment upgrades and additions for the United States Customs Service, such as weigh-in-motion sensors, AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, inbound commercial truck transponders, narcotics detectors, and license plate reader software. For fiscal year 1999, funding includes equipment upgrades for the United States Customs Service, such as weigh-in-motion sensors, AM radio stations, inbound vehicle counters, spotter camera systems, and inbound commercial truck transponders. Additionally, funds are allocated for narcotics detectors, license plate reader software, mobile truck x-rays, and ultrasonic container inspection units to enhance border patrol checkpoints. The funding for fiscal year 1999 includes equipment upgrades for the United States Customs Service at border patrol checkpoints, such as mobile truck x-rays, ultrasonic container inspection units, Portable Treasury Enforcement Communications System terminals, remote watch surveillance camera systems, AM radio stations, spotter camera systems, and narcotics vapor and particle detectors. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funding includes equipment maintenance and support for border patrol checkpoints, such as spotter camera systems and narcotics detectors. In fiscal year 2000 and beyond, funding includes equipment maintenance and support for border patrol checkpoints, such as spotter camera systems and narcotics detectors. Additionally, $1,509,000 shall be allocated for the maintenance and training of personnel for equipment described in subsection (b)(2) based on 10 percent of the equipment cost. The Commissioner of Customs may use appropriated funds for technologically superior equipment that achieves similar results at the same or lower cost than specified equipment in subsection (b)(1). In subsection (b)(1), technologically superior equipment can be used if it achieves the same results at a cost equal to or less than specified equipment. The Commissioner of Customs can reallocate up to 10 percent of funds for equipment in subsection (b)(1) to other specified equipment. The Attorney General has similar authority for equipment in subsection (b)(2) as the Commissioner of Customs for equipment in subsection (b)(1). In subsection (b)(1), technologically superior equipment can be used if it achieves the same results at a cost equal to or less than specified equipment. The Attorney General shall have the same authority as the Commissioner of Customs for equipment in subsection (b)(2). For fiscal years 1999 and 2000, funds are allocated for increased inspectors and agents at border crossings to enhance investigative resources and process cargo efficiently. The proposal includes a net increase of 285 inspectors and canine enforcement officers at large cargo facilities on the Southwest border, a net increase of 360 special agents and resources for drug smuggling and money-laundering efforts, a net increase of 50 positions and resources for anticorruption efforts, and covers the costs of personnel hired under this section. The proposal includes a net increase of 535 inspectors for the Southwest land border, 375 inspectors for the Northern land border, 100 inspectors and canine enforcement officers for border patrol checkpoints, and 100 canine enforcement vehicles for the Border Patrol. The proposal also includes a net increase of 40 intelligence analysts and additional resources for border patrol sectors focusing on drug smuggling and money-laundering, 50 positions and resources for anticorruption efforts at the Department of Justice's Inspector General Office, and covers the costs of the proposed increases. The proposal includes a net increase of 50 positions and additional resources for the Office of the Inspector General of the Department of Justice to enhance investigative resources for anticorruption efforts.
